prompts.prompt: In the sentence 'Dīcō puellam bonam esse' (I say that the girl is good), why is 'puellam' in the accusative case? Isn't it the direct object of 'dīcō'?

criteria: Explains that puellam is the SUBJECT of the infinitive esse, not object of dīcō
Notes that subjects of infinitives go into accusative case in Latin
May mention that the entire acc + inf construction is what you're 'saying'
Shows clear understanding of the distinction
excellent.example_response: Puellam is NOT the direct object of dīcō. It's the subject of the infinitive 'esse' - the girl is the one 'being good.' In Latin, the subject of an infinitive is always in the accusative case. The whole statement 'puellam bonam esse' is what I'm saying - that's the object of dīcō, not just puellam by itself.

criteria: Correctly identifies puellam as subject of infinitive
Understands it's accusative because it's subject of infinitive
May lack full explanation of why
good.example_response: It's the subject of the infinitive esse, not the object of dīcō. Subjects of infinitives are accusative.

prompts.prompt: What's the difference between 'Dīcit puellam esse bonam' and 'Dīxit puellam esse bonam'? They both have the same infinitive (esse), so why do they translate differently?

criteria: Explains that infinitive tense is RELATIVE to the main verb
First sentence: present main verb + present inf = same time = 'is'
Second sentence: past main verb + present inf = same time (in past) = 'was'
Shows understanding that esse translates differently based on when the main verb happens
May reference the concept of relative vs. absolute time
excellent.example_response: The infinitive tense is relative to the main verb's time. In 'Dīcit puellam esse bonam,' the present infinitive (esse) shows the same time as the present main verb (dīcit), so it translates as 'is' - 'He says that the girl IS good.' In 'Dīxit puellam esse bonam,' the same present infinitive shows the same time as the PAST main verb (dīxit), so it translates as 'was' - 'He said that the girl WAS good.' The infinitive's tense shows relationship to the main verb, not absolute time.

criteria: Recognizes that main verb tense affects translation
Correctly translates both sentences
May not fully articulate the 'relative time' concept
good.example_response: Dīcit is present so it's 'he says that the girl IS good.' Dīxit is past so it's 'he said that the girl WAS good.' The main verb changes the translation.

prompts.prompt: Look at this sentence: 'Putō rēgem mīlitēs vidēre.' There are two accusatives here - 'rēgem' and 'mīlitēs'. How do you know which one is the subject of the indirect statement and which one is the object?

criteria: Identifies rēgem as subject of infinitive (accusative subject)
Identifies mīlitēs as object of infinitive (accusative object)
Explains how to determine: syntax and meaning (who does the action of the infinitive?)
Translates correctly: 'I think that the king sees the soldiers'
Shows understanding that both can be accusative with different functions
excellent.example_response: Both are accusative, but they have different functions. rēgem is the subject of the infinitive vidēre - the king is the one doing the seeing. mīlitēs is the object of vidēre - the soldiers are what's being seen. You figure it out by asking: who does the action of the infinitive? (rēgem = subject) What receives the action? (mīlitēs = object). The translation is 'I think that the king sees the soldiers.'

criteria: Correctly identifies which is subject and which is object
Provides reasonable explanation
Translates correctly or mostly correctly
good.example_response: rēgem is the subject and mīlitēs is the object. The king is doing the seeing, so he's the subject. It means 'I think that the king sees the soldiers.'

prompts.prompt: What's the difference between 'Dīcit puellam esse bonam' (present infinitive) and 'Dīcit puellam fuisse bonam' (perfect infinitive)? Both have the same main verb (dīcit), so why do they mean different things?

criteria: Explains that present infinitive = same time, perfect infinitive = prior time
First: 'He says that the girl IS good' (she is good NOW, when he says it)
Second: 'He says that the girl WAS good' (she was good EARLIER, before he says it now)
Shows clear understanding of how infinitive type changes the time relationship
May note this is RELATIVE time, not absolute
excellent.example_response: The infinitive type shows WHEN the action happens relative to the main verb. With 'esse' (present infinitive), the girl 'being good' happens at the SAME TIME as he says it, so: 'He says that the girl IS good now.' With 'fuisse' (perfect infinitive), the girl 'being good' happened BEFORE he says it, so: 'He says that the girl WAS good (earlier).' Present infinitive = simultaneous; perfect infinitive = prior action.

criteria: Recognizes different infinitive types create different meanings
Translates both correctly
Generally understands time relationships
good.example_response: Esse is present infinitive so it's 'is good.' Fuisse is perfect infinitive so it's 'was good.' The perfect infinitive shows something that already happened.

criteria: Knows they're different infinitives
Uncertain about how time works
May translate one correctly
developing.example_response: Fuisse is perfect so it's past somehow?

criteria: Cannot explain or doesn't see a difference
Doesn't understand infinitive types
Translates both the same
insufficient.example_response: They both mean the same thing, don't they?

follow_up_if_good: Perfect! Now the really tricky one: how would 'DĪXIT puellam fuisse bonam' translate? (past main verb + perfect infinitive)
Excellent! What would a future infinitive look like, and what time relationship would it show?

prompts.prompt: Which of these verbs can introduce indirect statement: (a) dīcō (to say), (b) currō (to run), (c) putō (to think), (d) audiō (to hear), (e) videō (to see). Explain your choices.

criteria: Identifies dīcō, putō, audiō, videō as verbs that take indirect statement
Excludes currō (to run)
Explains the rule: verbs of saying, thinking, and perceiving take indirect statement
May provide the 'test': can you say 'I [verb] THAT...'?
excellent.example_response: dīcō, putō, audiō, and videō can all take indirect statement. dīcō is a verb of saying ('I say that...'), putō is a verb of thinking ('I think that...'), and audiō and videō are verbs of perceiving ('I hear that...' / 'I see that...'). currō (to run) cannot take indirect statement because you can't say 'I run that...' - it doesn't make sense. Only verbs of head, heart, and speech take indirect statement.

criteria: Correctly identifies which verbs can/cannot take indirect statement
Provides some reasoning
May reference categories (saying/thinking/perceiving)
good.example_response: All except currō. You can say 'I say that,' 'I think that,' 'I hear that,' and 'I see that,' but not 'I run that.'

criteria: Gets multiple wrong

prompts.prompt: In 'Crēdō vitam puellārum esse bonam,' there are two cases used - accusative (vitam, bonam) and genitive (puellārum). How do you know which noun is the subject of the indirect statement?

criteria: Identifies vitam as the accusative subject (life is what 'is good')
Identifies puellārum as genitive modifier (whose life? the girls')
Explains that only the ACCUSATIVE can be the subject of the infinitive
Shows understanding that genitive modifies the accusative subject
Translates: 'I believe that the girls' life is good'
excellent.example_response: The subject of the indirect statement is vitam (life), which is accusative. puellārum is genitive plural, meaning 'of the girls' or 'the girls'' - it's not the subject, it just modifies vitam to show whose life we're talking about. The rule is that the subject of an infinitive is always accusative, never genitive. So vitam (life) is what 'is good' (the subject), and puellārum tells us it's the girls' life. Translation: 'I believe that the girls' life is good.'

criteria: Correctly identifies vitam as subject
Recognizes puellārum as genitive modifier
Generally sound reasoning
Translates correctly or mostly correctly
good.example_response: vitam is the subject because it's accusative. puellārum is genitive, so it's possessive - 'the girls' life.' It means 'I believe that the girls' life is good.'

prompts.prompt: How do you form the perfect infinitive of a verb? Use 'amō, amāre, amāvī, amātus' as your example.

criteria: Explains the formation: perfect stem + -isse
Identifies perfect stem: amāv- (from third principal part amāvī, drop the -ī)
Forms perfect infinitive correctly: amāvisse
Provides translation: 'to have loved'
May note this works for all regular verbs
excellent.example_response: To form the perfect infinitive, you take the perfect stem and add -isse. For amō, the third principal part is amāvī. Drop the -ī to get the stem amāv-, then add -isse: amāvisse. This means 'to have loved.' This pattern works for all regular verbs - just take the perfect stem and add -isse.

criteria: Knows to use perfect stem + -isse
Forms amāvisse correctly
Generally correct explanation
good.example_response: You take amāv- from amāvī and add -isse, so amāvisse.

criteria: Partial understanding

developing.example_response: It's amāvisse, and it has -isse at the end.

criteria: Cannot form the infinitive

follow_up_if_good: Perfect! Now try forming the perfect infinitive of videō, vidēre, vīdī, vīsus.
